Definition: Application Programming Interface that allows communication and integration with other systems.
A sequence of steps or tasks that agents follow to complete a process.
An AI-powered tool that provides contextualized assistance throughout the software development lifecycle, including code completions, chat assistance, and code explanations.
A component that performs specific tasks, often with tools, knowledge, and instructions.
A group of agents that collaborate to achieve a common goal.
A connection point that allows agents to interact with external systems like Slack, WhatsApp, etc.
A repository of information that agents can access to answer questions or make decisions.
A utility or function that agents can use to perform specific tasks.
A system that allows agents to retain and recall information from previous interactions.
A component that directs tasks or information to the appropriate agent or step in a workflow.
The underlying AI model that powers the agent's reasoning and decision-making capabilities.
A runtime environment for running secure, high-performance agent systems in the cloud.
A management interface for monitoring and controlling the AgentOS.
Individual tasks or actions within a workflow that agents execute.
Integration points that allow agents to connect with external platforms like Slack, AISdk, etc.
A modular component in the Atomic Agents framework that performs a specific task, defined by input/output schemas and system prompts.
Configuration settings for an AtomicAgent, including client, model, system prompt, and history.
A base class for defining input and output schemas to ensure consistent data structure and validation.
Generates system prompts for agents, defining their behavior, steps, and output instructions.
Stores conversation history or other relevant data for an agent.
Components that inject dynamic context into an agent's system prompt at runtime.
A base class for creating context providers that supply dynamic information to agents.
A CLI tool for downloading and managing tools, agents, and pipelines in the Atomic Agents framework.
Specifies the structure and validation rules for the input data of an agent.
Specifies the structure and validation rules for the output data of an agent.
A task that automates a specific workflow or process within GitHub.
A server that runs workflows when they are triggered by events.
Retrieval-Augmented Generation framework that combines retrieval of relevant information with generative capabilities.
A feature that allows simultaneous testing across multiple operating systems and runtime versions.
A lightweight, standalone, executable package of software that includes everything needed to run it.
Content Delivery Network that provides fast and reliable distribution of packages and other content.
A way for GitHub to notify external services about events that occur within a repository.
Runners that you can host on your own infrastructure to execute workflows.
The ability to test multiple containers within a workflow, such as a web service and its database.
A token used to authenticate and authorize access to GitHub APIs and services.
A platform to discover and share actions created by the GitHub community.
A specific activity in a repository that triggers a workflow, such as a push or pull request.
The process of managing and resolving dependencies required for building and deploying software.
A secure storage for sensitive information used in workflows, such as API keys and tokens.
A feature that helps make sweeping changes by analyzing code, proposing edits, running tests, and validating results across multiple files.
A communication interface that allows developers to interact with GitHub Copilot using different AI models for various coding tasks.
A feature that analyzes code, uncovers hidden bugs, fixes mistakes, and provides feedback before human review.
A workflow automation tool used by GitHub Copilot to run code, test it, and deliver ready-to-review pull requests.
Servers that GitHub Copilot hooks into to draw on data from repositories and external resources.
Integrated Development Environment where GitHub Copilot provides code completions, chat assistance, and other features.
A mobile platform where GitHub Copilot is supported, providing access to various features and integrations.
Command Line Interface that supports GitHub Copilot, allowing interaction through terminals.
A terminal application where GitHub Copilot is supported as a chat integration.
The web platform where GitHub Copilot is natively integrated, providing various features and functionalities.
A feature or tool available in the Pro+ plan of GitHub Copilot, providing additional functionalities.
A feature that updates instantly as you build, allowing you to see your ideas take shape in real-time.
A platform that uses artificial intelligence to enhance and automate the development process.
Applications that encompass both front-end and back-end development, incorporating AI features.
The ability to publish and deploy applications with a single click, simplifying the deployment process.
Secure access to applications and services using GitHub's authentication system.
Visual Studio Code integrated with an AI agent to enhance coding and development.
Functionalities such as chatbots, content generation, and smart automation embedded within applications.
A system that records changes to files over time, allowing for collaboration and tracking of modifications.
The ability to work together with others on the same project, often facilitated by tools and platforms.
Creating functional prototypes quickly to demonstrate and iterate on ideas.
Custom applications built for individual use, often tailored to specific personal needs.
A platform or tool that helps validate and launch scalable Software as a Service (SaaS) applications.
Tools and features for building professional websites, including portfolios, landing pages, and marketing sites.
Prompts sent to Spark to generate or modify applications using natural language.
Active sessions where users can build and iterate on their applications.
The processing power and resources required to run and deploy applications.
The process of using AI models to make predictions or decisions based on input data.
The space and resources allocated for storing application data and files.
The service that provides the infrastructure to deploy and run applications on the internet.
A premium plan that includes advanced features and capabilities for GitHub Copilot users.
A feature in Spark that allows users to refine and modify their applications using natural language or visual controls.
The ability to adjust specific parts of an application using natural language or visual controls.
The environment in which applications run and are deployed, including necessary infrastructure and configurations.
A cloud-based development environment integrated with Visual Studio Code, allowing for seamless coding and collaboration.
An AI-powered tool that assists in coding and development, providing suggestions and automations.

A JavaScript library for building user interfaces, often used in conjunction with TypeScript.
A cloud computing platform that provides hosting, compute, and other services for deploying applications.

Inputs for AI models that can be versioned, shared, and reused like code.
Structured assessments to score AI outputs on quality, relevance, or custom metrics.
